After a period of inactivity during the mid-year examinations the
Dramatic Club is again hard at
work. Because of the marked success of the club's production of
"The Admirable Crichton," last
December, it has been definitely
decided to present the same play
again on April 22. The cast will
probably be much the same as before, and Miss Walter will again
be on hand to direct the dress rehearsal and the final production.
The Dramatic Club also plans
to present an "All Hopkins" show.
Two one-act plays written by students at the University are to be
produced entirely under the direction of the authors and members of the club without any outside assistance. As far as possible, the casts of these plays will
be made up of men who do not
have parts in "The Admirable
Crichton," so as to give the new
men an opportunity to display
their talent and also to avoid
placing too much work on one
group of men. The date on which
these plays will be given has not
yet been set, nor has it been definitely decided where they are to
be held. The first tryouts for the
cast were held on Monday, and
the work will be continued from
now on.

Faculty Notes.
• The latest number of the America,n Journal of Philology makes
the announcement that Professor
Basil L. Gildersleeve has retired
from the editorial staff of the
journal and that the sole editorship is now in the hands of Professor C. W. E. Miller.
The same issue contains contributions from various Hopkins professors and alumni. The articles
are as follows: "Cicero and the
Poetae Novi," by Professor Tenney
Frank; "Declension Exponents
and Case Endings," by the late
Professor Edwin W. Fay, of the
University of Texas; "The Wandering Skull, New Light on Tantrakhyana, 29," by Dr. W. Norman Brown, Johnston scholar in
Sanskrit; "Review, Hoffman's
Everyday Greek," by Professor C.
W. E. Miller; "Report on Revue
de Philologie," by Professor Win-

fred P. Mustard, and "Brief Mention," by Professor Basil L. Gildersleeve.
Professor Hollander, of the Political Economy Department, has
been appointed associate staff director of economic inquiries of
the Advisory Committee on Policies and Platforms of the Republican National Committee. He
will be in charge of the investigation on the high cost of living. He
has received the necessary leave of
absence for the rest of the year
from the University, as his headquarters will be in New York. Dr.
Hollander is compelled to leave
sometime this week. His classes
will be temporarily instructed by
other teachers of the University.

MAR. 9, 1920

Election Announcement.

THE NEWS-LETTER takes pleasure in announcing the election of
the following officers who will constitute the 1921 Board of Control,
which will go in office with the issue of March 16.
Editor-in-chief, Llewellyn W.
Lord, '21; managing editor, H.
Douglas Cotton, '22; business
manager, George Deichman, '20;
circulation manager, Frederick W.
Lipps, '22.
C. A. A. Constitution.
At a recent meeting of the General Athletic Association, the proposed new constitution of that
body was read, and then laid upon
the table until the next meeting
of the board on Thursday, March
11. In the meantime, all members
of the association are urged to acquaint themselves with the proposed changes, so that they may
be prepared to vote intelligently
at that meeting. A copy of the
document may be seen at the athletic office.
At the same meeting, it was
moved and passed that in the future, the Debating Council should
award some distinctive insignia
instead of the gold "H" as in
former years.

The Coalition Concert.
The concert next Wednesday
night will probably be the most
significant attempt that the Musical Clubs have made in the last
few years. With the return to
normal conditions in the University, the Musical Clubs, probably
as much as any other activity,have
gone to work in earnest and have
achieved notable results. The concerts this year have been exceptionally successful and enjoyable,
as the continued applause by the
audiences has indicated; the
clubs have increased in size and
talent, and have a repertoire at
once diversified and constantly
changing.
On March 10, the concert will be
given by our combined clubs in
conjunction with the musical organization of Goucher College,
which is known to be of avery high
order. This joint undertaking with
Goucher is in itself important,
and should increase the already
cordial relations of the two institutions, but aside from this advantage the musical entertainment
on March 10 will deserve success,
and a huge Hopkins audience.

Many Hopkins Men Entered—Squad
Cut Down by Black List.

On Saturday, March 13, the
track team will journey to Washington to take part in the indoor
meet held under the supervision
of the Catholic University. Although this meet will not be as
large as the one held here on February 28 in the Fifth Regiment
Armory, there will be numerous
stars present, and some of the
events should be very interesting.
During the past week the Hopkins
team has been practicing whenever the weather permitted, and
will continue to practice throughout this week.
As there will be no South Atlantic relay race, members of the
Black and Blue relay team will be
free to take part in other events
and should furnish some excellent
entries for the quarter and half
mile runs, both open and South
Atlantic. Owing to the fact that
the longest available straightaway
on the Washington track is 50
yards, there will be no 100 or 220
yard events. This explains why
several men on the squad are not
on the entry list.
During the past week the team
has both gained and lost. Bartow
Van Ness who, because of a recent illness, was unable to take
full part in the Armory meet, will
be back on the job in the 440. At
the same time, the black list has
been published, thus barring several men.from competitions.

sent in by Manager Cox is as
follows:

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 9, 1920.

6

LACROSSE PROSPECTS BRIGHT

DR. JOSEPH S. AMES LECTURES

Many Old Men Back and Large Squad
of Promising New Material—First
Game Is With Cornell on April 3.

"Einstein's Theory of Gravitation"
Subject of His Address to Undergraduate Body.

In spite of adverse weather conditions, the lacrosse squad has
been holding practice on Straus
field for several weeks. Owing to
the large number of letter men
who are back and the abundance
of new material, the team promises to be entirely up to the standard set by teams of previous years.
With the coming of warmer
weather the team should develop
even more rapidly, and by the
time of the opening game against
Cornell, which will be played at
Homewood on April 3, it should
be in excellent condition.
A large number of last year's
stars have already reported at
practice, and still others are expected to show up later. Silberstein is back on the job at first attack, and Dougherty and Sadtler
will probably hold down the position of goal. Captain Meyer at
first defense, Morley at point, Stuart and Defandorf at out home,
and Hoffman and Cashell on the
attack form the nucleus for an extremely formidable organization.
"Tiff" Williams, who is now at the
Medical School, is still eligible,
and will probably fill his old position at center.
Manager Keys is rapidly completing the work of making out
the schedule. At present, games
have been arranged with the following teams:
April 3, Cornell.
April 10, Alumni.
April 17, Open.
April 24, Harvard.
May 1, Open.
May 8, Swarthmore.
May 15, Stevens.
May 22, Pennsylvania.
May 29, Lehigh.
• With the exception of the
Swarthmore and Penn games, all
the contests will take place at
Homewood.
There are a great many new
men who are showing good form
and who may crowd out some of
the older and more experienced
men. Among the more promising
of these are Butler, "Billy" Hoffman, Melamet, Benedick, a former
City College star, and A. V. D.
Smith, who was a member of the
Navy squad last year.
R. O. T. C.

Six members of the R. 0. T. C.
unit have been selected for training as experts in signal work
under Lieutenant Cattanach. The
new signallers are the following:
Davis, H. J., West, Miller, Rawlins, Wallace and Kuder.
One sand table has been completed by the Junior R. 0. T. C.
members and is to be photographed. The pictures of these
sand tables will be hung in the
military rooms with the names of
those who have made them attached to the pictures.

On last Tuesday, the Hopkins
undergraduate body, as well as
many interested graduates and
professors enjoyed a lecture such
as but few are privileged to hear.
"Einstein's Theory of Gravitation," so important, so far-reaching, and at the present time so
prominent, is thoroughly understood only by the mot advanced
mathematicians and physicists.
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, well-known
to all Johns Hopkins students as
the head of the Physics Department, and equally well-known in
the scientific world as a great physicist, undertook to explain the
fundamental principles of this
new theory.
Contrary to the impression of
the general public, Einstein's law
of gravitation is not disproved,
but is merely shown to be limited
to certain cases. Einstein's theory
is not limited to any particular
cases, it embraces all that could
possibly occur either on the planets or in space. When a body is
moving slowly, and the speed of
the earth and all planetary bodies
are comparatively slow, Einstein's
general formula reduces to the
form of "Newton's Law of Gravitation ;" but with high speed bodies, such as light, no such reduction is possible, and this more intricate equation must be retained.
Einstein's method of arriving at
these formulas or equations is different from that commonly employed. He does not attempt to
deduce formulas or make explanations, but simply makes postui
lates and draws conclusions from
them by means of mathematics.
This method has two important
characteristics: First—It leads to
predictions which no one would
have looked for. Second—Unless
the theory is fulfilled, it is cast
away.
Following this method, Einstein
arrived at the following postulates: First—The Principle of
Relativity. Dr. Ames explained
this principle by means of
the railroad. Illustration: If
two trains are running along
at the same speed on parallel tracks, one train appears
stationary to an observer in the
other. If, however, the speed of
one should change, the observer
cannot know which one did
change, but can only note the relative change in speed. Second—
No matter what the source may
be, light always has the same
velocity. Third—All observations
in nature are observations of coincidence.
The position of a body is always
determined with reference to another. A scale of co-ordinates or ,
• a reference plane must be designated in order to definitely fix the
position of a body. This postu(Continued on page 7, col. 2)

helped to make this lecture one of

Tryouts for the Junior Debating Team were held Tuesday,
March 2, and the following team
was chosen: chairman, C. I. T.
Gould, Jr.; first speaker, Mervin
Deems; second speaker, Harold
Reed. Gould will take care of
the rebuttal.
The contest will be held on
March 27, in Civil Engineering
Hall, where the Juniors will
attempt to prove the desirability of a system of universal military training for the
United States, in spite of the objections of the seniors that such a
system would prove most undesirable. The seniors have popular
sentiment and lots of valuable
past experience on their side,
while the juniors are confident of
victory in spite of the fact that
the burden of proof rests upon
them. The contest is extremely
pertinent at the present time in
view of the discussion now going
on in Congress, and the fact that
the question of military training
will probably form one plank of
the Republican platform in the
coming presidential campaign

After a period of inactivity during the mid-year examinations the
Dramatic Club is again hard at
work. Because of the marked success of the club's production of
"The Admirable Crichton," last
December, it has been definitely
decided to present the same play
again on April 22. The cast will
probably be much the same as before, and Miss Walter will again
be on hand to direct the dress rehearsal and the final production.
The Dramatic Club also plans
to present an "All Hopkins" show.
Two one-act plays written by students at the University are to be
produced entirely under the direction of the authors and members of the club without any outside assistance. As far as possible, the casts of these plays will
be made up of men who do not
have parts in "The Admirable
Crichton," so as to give the new
men an opportunity to display
their talent and also to avoid
placing too much work on one
group of men. The date on which
these plays will be given has not
yet been set, nor has it been definitely decided where they are to
be held. The first tryouts for the
cast were held on Monday, and
the work will be continued from
now on.

Faculty Notes.
• The latest number of the America,n Journal of Philology makes
the announcement that Professor
Basil L. Gildersleeve has retired
from the editorial staff of the
journal and that the sole editorship is now in the hands of Professor C. W. E. Miller.
The same issue contains contributions from various Hopkins professors and alumni. The articles
are as follows: "Cicero and the
Poetae Novi," by Professor Tenney
Frank; "Declension Exponents
and Case Endings," by the late
Professor Edwin W. Fay, of the
University of Texas; "The Wandering Skull, New Light on Tantrakhyana, 29," by Dr. W. Norman Brown, Johnston scholar in
Sanskrit; "Review, Hoffman's
Everyday Greek," by Professor C.
W. E. Miller; "Report on Revue
de Philologie," by Professor Win-

Professor Hollander, of the Political Economy Department, has
been appointed associate staff director of economic inquiries of
the Advisory Committee on Policies and Platforms of the Republican National Committee. He
will be in charge of the investigation on the high cost of living. He
has received the necessary leave of
absence for the rest of the year
from the University, as his headquarters will be in New York. Dr.
Hollander is compelled to leave
sometime this week. His classes
will be temporarily instructed by
other teachers of the University.

MAR. 9, 1920

Election Announcement.

THE NEWS-LETTER takes pleasure in announcing the election of
the following officers who will constitute the 1921 Board of Control,
which will go in office with the issue of March 16.
Editor-in-chief, Llewellyn W.
Lord, '21; managing editor, H.
Douglas Cotton, '22; business
manager, George Deichman, '20;
circulation manager, Frederick W.
Lipps, '22.
C. A. A. Constitution.
At a recent meeting of the General Athletic Association, the proposed new constitution of that
body was read, and then laid upon
the table until the next meeting
of the board on Thursday, March
11. In the meantime, all members
of the association are urged to acquaint themselves with the proposed changes, so that they may
be prepared to vote intelligently
at that meeting. A copy of the
document may be seen at the athletic office.
At the same meeting, it was
moved and passed that in the future, the Debating Council should
award some distinctive insignia
instead of the gold "H" as in
former years.

The Coalition Concert.
The concert next Wednesday
night will probably be the most
significant attempt that the Musical Clubs have made in the last
few years. With the return to
normal conditions in the University, the Musical Clubs, probably
as much as any other activity,have
gone to work in earnest and have
achieved notable results. The concerts this year have been exceptionally successful and enjoyable,
as the continued applause by the
audiences has indicated; the
clubs have increased in size and
talent, and have a repertoire at
once diversified and constantly
changing.
On March 10, the concert will be
given by our combined clubs in
conjunction with the musical organization of Goucher College,
which is known to be of avery high
order. This joint undertaking with
Goucher is in itself important,
and should increase the already
cordial relations of the two institutions, but aside from this advantage the musical entertainment
on March 10 will deserve success,
and a huge Hopkins audience.

Many Hopkins Men Entered—Squad
Cut Down by Black List.

On Saturday, March 13, the
track team will journey to Washington to take part in the indoor
meet held under the supervision
of the Catholic University. Although this meet will not be as
large as the one held here on February 28 in the Fifth Regiment
Armory, there will be numerous
stars present, and some of the
events should be very interesting.
During the past week the Hopkins
team has been practicing whenever the weather permitted, and
will continue to practice throughout this week.
As there will be no South Atlantic relay race, members of the
Black and Blue relay team will be
free to take part in other events
and should furnish some excellent
entries for the quarter and half
mile runs, both open and South
Atlantic. Owing to the fact that
the longest available straightaway
on the Washington track is 50
yards, there will be no 100 or 220
yard events. This explains why
several men on the squad are not
on the entry list.
During the past week the team
has both gained and lost. Bartow
Van Ness who, because of a recent illness, was unable to take
full part in the Armory meet, will
be back on the job in the 440. At
the same time, the black list has
been published, thus barring several men.from competitions.

sent in by Manager Cox is as
follows:

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 9, 1920.

6

LACROSSE PROSPECTS BRIGHT

DR. JOSEPH S. AMES LECTURES

Many Old Men Back and Large Squad
of Promising New Material—First
Game Is With Cornell on April 3.

"Einstein's Theory of Gravitation"
Subject of His Address to Undergraduate Body.

In spite of adverse weather conditions, the lacrosse squad has
been holding practice on Straus
field for several weeks. Owing to
the large number of letter men
who are back and the abundance
of new material, the team promises to be entirely up to the standard set by teams of previous years.
With the coming of warmer
weather the team should develop
even more rapidly, and by the
time of the opening game against
Cornell, which will be played at
Homewood on April 3, it should
be in excellent condition.
A large number of last year's
stars have already reported at
practice, and still others are expected to show up later. Silberstein is back on the job at first attack, and Dougherty and Sadtler
will probably hold down the position of goal. Captain Meyer at
first defense, Morley at point, Stuart and Defandorf at out home,
and Hoffman and Cashell on the
attack form the nucleus for an extremely formidable organization.
"Tiff" Williams, who is now at the
Medical School, is still eligible,
and will probably fill his old position at center.
Manager Keys is rapidly completing the work of making out
the schedule. At present, games
have been arranged with the following teams:
April 3, Cornell.
April 10, Alumni.
April 17, Open.
April 24, Harvard.
May 1, Open.
May 8, Swarthmore.
May 15, Stevens.
May 22, Pennsylvania.
May 29, Lehigh.
• With the exception of the
Swarthmore and Penn games, all
the contests will take place at
Homewood.
There are a great many new
men who are showing good form
and who may crowd out some of
the older and more experienced
men. Among the more promising
of these are Butler, "Billy" Hoffman, Melamet, Benedick, a former
City College star, and A. V. D.
Smith, who was a member of the
Navy squad last year.
R. O. T. C.

Six members of the R. 0. T. C.
unit have been selected for training as experts in signal work
under Lieutenant Cattanach. The
new signallers are the following:
Davis, H. J., West, Miller, Rawlins, Wallace and Kuder.
One sand table has been completed by the Junior R. 0. T. C.
members and is to be photographed. The pictures of these
sand tables will be hung in the
military rooms with the names of
those who have made them attached to the pictures.

On last Tuesday, the Hopkins
undergraduate body, as well as
many interested graduates and
professors enjoyed a lecture such
as but few are privileged to hear.
"Einstein's Theory of Gravitation," so important, so far-reaching, and at the present time so
prominent, is thoroughly understood only by the mot advanced
mathematicians and physicists.
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, well-known
to all Johns Hopkins students as
the head of the Physics Department, and equally well-known in
the scientific world as a great physicist, undertook to explain the
fundamental principles of this
new theory.
Contrary to the impression of
the general public, Einstein's law
of gravitation is not disproved,
but is merely shown to be limited
to certain cases. Einstein's theory
is not limited to any particular
cases, it embraces all that could
possibly occur either on the planets or in space. When a body is
moving slowly, and the speed of
the earth and all planetary bodies
are comparatively slow, Einstein's
general formula reduces to the
form of "Newton's Law of Gravitation ;" but with high speed bodies, such as light, no such reduction is possible, and this more intricate equation must be retained.
Einstein's method of arriving at
these formulas or equations is different from that commonly employed. He does not attempt to
deduce formulas or make explanations, but simply makes postui
lates and draws conclusions from
them by means of mathematics.
This method has two important
characteristics: First—It leads to
predictions which no one would
have looked for. Second—Unless
the theory is fulfilled, it is cast
away.
Following this method, Einstein
arrived at the following postulates: First—The Principle of
Relativity. Dr. Ames explained
this principle by means of
the railroad. Illustration: If
two trains are running along
at the same speed on parallel tracks, one train appears
stationary to an observer in the
other. If, however, the speed of
one should change, the observer
cannot know which one did
change, but can only note the relative change in speed. Second—
No matter what the source may
be, light always has the same
velocity. Third—All observations
in nature are observations of coincidence.
The position of a body is always
determined with reference to another. A scale of co-ordinates or ,
• a reference plane must be designated in order to definitely fix the
position of a body. This postu(Continued on page 7, col. 2)

Tryouts for the Junior Debating Team were held Tuesday,
March 2, and the following team
was chosen: chairman, C. I. T.
Gould, Jr.; first speaker, Mervin
Deems; second speaker, Harold
Reed. Gould will take care of
the rebuttal.
The contest will be held on
March 27, in Civil Engineering
Hall, where the Juniors will
attempt to prove the desirability of a system of universal military training for the
United States, in spite of the objections of the seniors that such a
system would prove most undesirable. The seniors have popular
sentiment and lots of valuable
past experience on their side,
while the juniors are confident of
victory in spite of the fact that
the burden of proof rests upon
them. The contest is extremely
pertinent at the present time in
view of the discussion now going
on in Congress, and the fact that
the question of military training
will probably form one plank of
the Republican platform in the
coming presidential campaign
